A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraic Closure of Finite Field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand whether the concept of a set is necessary for defining an algebraic closure of a finite field, we need to analyze the components of the definition of an algebraic closure. The definition of an algebraic closure of a finite field involves the concept of a field that contains another field and all its algebraic extensions. A field, in mathematical terms, is a set equipped with two operations (addition and multiplication) that satisfy certain axioms. Therefore, the very notion of a field presupposes the concept of a set, as a field is fundamentally a particular kind of set with additional structure.\n\nMoreover, the definition of an algebraic closure involves the containment of multiple fields, which are themselves sets, and the idea of algebraic extensions, which also rely on the notion of sets of elements satisfying polynomial equations. Thus, the concept of a set is inherently used in defining what a field is and by extension in defining an algebraic closure of a finite field. Without the concept of a set, the structure and properties of fields, and consequently the definition of an algebraic closure, would not be comprehensible or well-defined.
